00020 //    This file contains basic definitions for points, rectangles and
00021 //    distance computations, which have been taken from ANN.  These
00022 //    are heavily used by the kc-tree, which was adapted from ANN's
00023 //    kd-tree routines.
00024 //----------------------------------------------------------------------
00025

00027 #define KM_ANN_H

00042 //----------------------------------------------------------------------
00043 //  Basic Types:  KMcoord, KMdist, KMidx
00044 //    KMcoord and KMdist are the types used for representing
00045 //    point coordinates and distances.  They can be modified by the
00046 //    user, with some care.  It is assumed that they are both numeric
00047 //    types, and that KMdist is generally of an equal or higher type
00048 //    from KMcoord.  A variable of type KMdist should be large
00049 //    enough to store the sum of squared components of a variable
00050 //    of type KMcoord for the number of dimensions needed in the
00051 //    application.  For example, the following combinations are
00052 //    legal:
00053 //
00054 //        KMcoord    KMdist
00055 //        ---------    -------------------------------
00056 //        short        short, int, long, float, double
00057 //        int        int, long, float, double
00058 //        long        long, float, double
00059 //        float        float, double
00060 //        double        double
00061 //
00062 //    It is the user's responsibility to make sure that overflow does
00063 //    not occur in distance calculation.
00064 //
00065 //    The code assumes that there is an infinite distance, KM_DIST_INF
00066 //    (as large as any legal distance).  Possible values are given below:
00067 //
00068 //        Examples:
00069 //        KMdist:        double, float, long, int, short
00070 //        KM_DIST_INF:    DBL_MAX, FLT_MAX, LONG_MAX, INT_MAX, SHRT_MAX
00071 //
00072 //    The routine that dumps a tree needs to know roughly how many
00073 //    significant digits there are in a KMcoord, so it can output
00074 //    points to full precision.  This is defined in KMcoordPrec.
00075 //    If you have ANSI C++, you should be able to use the following
00076 //    values from values.h to help in computing this:
00077 //
00078 //        KMcoord            KMcoordBits
00079 //        --------------------    -------------------------------
00080 //        short, int, long,...    BITS(short), BITS(int), ...
00081 //        float            FSIGNIF
00082 //        double            DSIGNIF
00083 //
00084 //    Then KMcoordPrec = KMcoordBits/(log_2 10) where log_2 10
00085 //    is the base 2 logarithm of 10.
00086 //
00087 //    KMidx is a point index.  When the data structure is built,
00088 //    the points are given as an array.  Nearest neighbor results are
00089 //    returned as an index into this array.  To make it clearer when
00090 //    this is happening, we define the integer type KMidx.
00091 //        
00092 //----------------------------------------------------------------------
00093 
00094 typedef    double    KMcoord;        // coordinate data type
00095 typedef    double    KMdist;            // distance data type
00096 typedef int    KMidx;            // point index
00097 
00098                     // largest possible distance
00099 const KMdist    KM_DIST_INF    =  DBL_MAX;
00100 
00101 #ifdef DSIGNIF                // number of sig. digits in KMcoord
00102     const int     KMcoordPrec    = DBL_DIG;
00103 #else
00104     const int     KMcoordPrec    = 15;    // default precision
00105 #endif
00106 
00107 //----------------------------------------------------------------------
00108 //  Norms and metrics:
00109 //    KM supports any Minkowski norm for defining distance.  In
00110 //    particular, for any p >= 1, the L_p Minkowski norm defines the
00111 //    length of a d-vector (v0, v1, ..., v(d-1)) to be
00112 //
00113 //        (|v0|^p + |v1|^p + ... + |v(d-1)|^p)^(1/p),
00114 //
00115 //    (where ^ denotes exponentiation, and |.| denotes absolute
00116 //    value).  The distance between two points is defined to be
00117 //    the norm of the vector joining them.  Some common distance
00118 //    metrics include
00119 //
00120 //        Euclidean metric    p = 2
00121 //        Manhattan metric    p = 1
00122 //        Max metric        p = infinity
00123 //
00124 //    In the case of the max metric, the norm is computed by
00125 //    taking the maxima of the absolute values of the components.
00126 //    KM is highly "coordinate-based" and does not support general
00127 //    distances functions (e.g. those obeying just the triangle
00128 //    inequality).  It also does not support distance functions
00129 //    based on inner-products.
00130 //
00131 //    For the purpose of computing nearest neighbors, it is not
00132 //    necessary to compute the final power (1/p).  Thus the only
00133 //    component that is used by the program is |v(i)|^p.
00134 //
00135 //    KM parameterizes the distance computation through the following
00136 //    macros.  (Macros are used rather than procedures for efficiency.)
00137 //    Recall that the distance between two points is given by the length
00138 //    of the vector joining them, and the length or norm of a vector v
00139 //    is given by formula:
00140 //
00141 //        |v| = ROOT(POW(v0) # POW(v1) # ... # POW(v(d-1)))
00142 //
00143 //    where ROOT, POW are unary functions and # is an associative and
00144 //    commutative binary operator satisfying:
00145 //
00146 //        **    POW:    coord        --> dist
00147 //        **    #:    dist x dist    --> dist
00148 //        **    ROOT:    dist (>0)    --> double
00149 //
00150 //    For early termination in distance calculation (partial distance
00151 //    calculation) we assume that POW and # together are monotonically
00152 //    increasing on sequences of arguments, meaning that for all
00153 //    v0..vk and y:
00154 //
00155 //    POW(v0) #...# POW(vk) <= (POW(v0) #...# POW(vk)) # POW(y).
00156 //
00157 //    Due to the use of incremental distance calculations in the code
00158 //    for searching k-d trees, we assume that there is an incremental
00159 //    update function DIFF(x,y) for #, such that if:
00160 //
00161 //            s = x0 # ... # xi # ... # xk 
00162 //
00163 //    then if s' is s with xi replaced by y, that is, 
00164 //    
00165 //            s' = x0 # ... # y # ... # xk
00166 //
00167 //    can be computed by:
00168 //
00169 //            s' = s # DIFF(xi,y).
00170 //
00171 //    Thus, if # is + then DIFF(xi,y) is (yi-x).  For the L_infinity
00172 //    norm we make use of the fact that in the program this function
00173 //    is only invoked when y > xi, and hence DIFF(xi,y)=y.
00174 //
00175 //    Finally, for approximate nearest neighbor queries we assume
00176 //    that POW and ROOT are related such that
00177 //
00178 //            v*ROOT(x) = ROOT(POW(v)*x)
00179 //
00180 //    Here are the values for the various Minkowski norms:
00181 //
00182 //    L_p:    p even:                p odd:
00183 //        -------------------------    ------------------------
00184 //        POW(v)        = v^p        POW(v)        = |v|^p
00185 //        ROOT(x)        = x^(1/p)    ROOT(x)        = x^(1/p)
00186 //        #        = +        #        = +
00187 //        DIFF(x,y)    = y - x        DIFF(x,y)    = y - x    
00188 //
00189 //    L_inf:
00190 //        POW(v)        = |v|
00191 //        ROOT(x)        = x
00192 //        #        = max
00193 //        DIFF(x,y)      = y
00194 //
00195 //    By default the Euclidean norm is assumed.  To change the norm,
00196 //    uncomment the appropriate set of macros below.
00197 //
00198 //----------------------------------------------------------------------
00199 
00200 //----------------------------------------------------------------------
00201 //    Use the following for the Euclidean norm
00202 //----------------------------------------------------------------------
00203 #define KM_POW(v)        ((v)*(v))
00204 #define KM_ROOT(x)        sqrt(x)
00205 #define KM_SUM(x,y)        ((x) + (y))
00206 #define KM_DIFF(x,y)        ((y) - (x))
00207 
00208 //----------------------------------------------------------------------
00209 //  Array types
00210 //
00211 //  KMpoint:
00212 //    A point is represented as a (dimensionless) vector of
00213 //    coordinates, that is, as a pointer to KMcoord.  It is the
00214 //    user's responsibility to be sure that each such vector has
00215 //    been allocated with enough components.  Because only
00216 //    pointers are stored, the values should not be altered
00217 //    through the lifetime of the nearest neighbor data structure.
00218 //  KMpointArray is a dimensionless array of KMpoint.
00219 //  KMdistArray is a dimensionless array of KMdist.
00220 //  KMidxArray is a dimensionless array of KMidx.  This is used for
00221 //    storing buckets of points in the search trees, and for returning
00222 //    the results of k nearest neighbor queries.
00223 //----------------------------------------------------------------------
00224 
00225 typedef KMcoord        *KMpoint;        // a point
00226 typedef KMpoint     *KMpointArray;        // an array of points 
00227 typedef KMdist      *KMdistArray;        // an array of distances 
00228 typedef KMidx        *KMidxArray;        // an array of point indices
00229 
00230 //----------------------------------------------------------------------
00231 //  Point utilities:
00232 //
00233 //    kmDist(dim, p, q)
00234 //      Returns the squared distances between p and q.
00235 //
00236 //    kmEqualPts(dim, p, q)
00237 //      Returns true if p and q are the same points.
00238 //
00239 //----------------------------------------------------------------------
00240 //----------------------------------------------------------------------
00241 //  Point and Point-array Allocation/Deallocation:
00242 //
00243 //    Because points (somewhat like strings in C) are stored as
00244 //    pointers.  Consequently, creating and destroying copies of
00245 //    points may require storage allocation.  These procedures do
00246 //    this.
00247 //
00248 //    p = kmAllocPt(dim, c=0)
00249 //      Allocates storage for a single point, and return a pointer
00250 //      to it.  The second argument is used to initialize all the
00251 //      points components.
00252 //
00253 //    kmDeallocPt(p)
00254 //      Deallocates a point allocated by kmAllocPt().
00255 //
00256 //    pa = kmAllocPts(n, dim)
00257 //      Allocates an array of n points in dimension d.  It performs
00258 //      no initialization.
00259 //
00260 //     kmDeallocPts(pa)
00261 //      Deallocates points allocated by kmAllocPts().
00262 //----------------------------------------------------------------------
00263    
00264 KMdist kmDist(                // compute squared distance
00265     int            dim,            // dimension of space
00266     KMpoint        p,            // points
00267     KMpoint        q);
00268 
00269 bool kmEqualPts(            // are two points equal?
00270     int            dim,            // dimension
00271     KMpoint        p1,            // the points
00272     KMpoint        p2);
00273 
00274 KMpoint kmAllocPt(            // allocate point storage
00275     int            dim,            // dimension
00276     KMcoord        c = 0);            // coordinate value (all equal)
00277 
00278 void kmDeallocPt(            // deallocate a point
00279     KMpoint        &p);
00280 
00281 KMpointArray kmAllocPts(        // allocate point array
00282     int            n,            // number of points
00283     int            dim);            // dimension
00284    
00285 void kmDeallocPts(            // deallocate a point array
00286     KMpointArray    &pa);            // the array
00287 
00288 //----------------------------------------------------------------------
00289 //  Point and other type copying:
00290 //
00291 //    kmCopyPt(dim, source, dest)
00292 //      Copies point source to point dest, without allocation.
00293 //
00294 //    dest = kmAllocCopyPt(dim, source)
00295 //      Allocates storage for and copies a point source to dest.
00296 //
00297 //    kmCopyPts(n, dim, source, dest)
00298 //      Copies point array source to point dest, without allocation.
00299 //
00300 //    dest = kmAllocCopyPts(n, dim, source)
00301 //      Allocates storage for and copies a point array source to dest.
00302 //
00303 //    kmCopy(n, source, dest)
00304 //      A generic copy routine for any time for which "=" is defined.
00305 //
00306 //    kmAllocCopy(n, source, dest)
00307 //      A generic allocate and copy routine for any time for which
00308 //      "=" is defined.
00309 //----------------------------------------------------------------------
00310 
00311 void kmCopyPt(                // copy point without allocation
00312     int            dim,            // dimension
00313     KMpoint        source,            // source point
00314     KMpoint        dest);            // destination point
00315 
00316 KMpoint kmAllocCopyPt(            // allocate and copy point
00317     int            dim,            // dimension
00318     KMpoint        source);        // point to copy
00319 
00320 void kmCopyPts(                // copy point array without allocation
00321     int            n,            // number of points
00322     int            dim,            // dimension
00323     const KMpointArray    source,            // source point
00324     KMpointArray    dest);            // destination point
00325 
00326 KMpointArray kmAllocCopyPts(        // allocate and copy point array
00327     int            n,            // number of points
00328     int            dim,            // dimension
00329     const KMpointArray    source);        // source point
00330 
00331 template <typename Object>
00332 void kmCopy(                // copy anything without allocation
00333     int            n,            // number of object
00334     const Object*    source,            // source array
00335     Object*        dest)            // destination array
00336 {
00337     for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {        // copy contents
00338         dest[i] = source[i];
00339     }
00340 }
00341 
00342 template <typename Object>
00343 Object* kmAllocCopy(            // allocate and copy anything
00344     int            n,            // number of object
00345     const Object*    source)            // source array
00346 {
00347     Object* dest = new Object[n];        // allocate array
00348     for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {        // copy contents
00349         dest[i] = source[i];
00350     }
00351     return dest;
00352 }

00363 //----------------------------------------------------------------------
00364 //  Orthogonal (axis aligned) rectangle
00365 //    Orthogonal rectangles are represented by two points, one
00366 //    for the lower left corner (min coordinates) and the other
00367 //    for the upper right corner (max coordinates).
00368 //
00369 //    The constructor initializes from either a pair of coordinates,
00370 //    pair of points, or another rectangle.  Note that all constructors
00371 //    allocate new point storage.  The destructor deallocates this
00372 //    storage.
00373 //
00374 //    BEWARE: Orthogonal rectangles should be passed ONLY BY REFERENCE.
00375 //    (C++'s default copy constructor will not allocate new point
00376 //    storage, then on return the destructor free's storage, and then
00377 //    you get into big trouble in the calling procedure.)
00378 //----------------------------------------------------------------------
00379 
00380 class KMorthRect {
00381 public:
00382     KMpoint    lo;            // rectangle lower bounds
00383     KMpoint    hi;            // rectangle upper bounds
00384 //
00385     KMorthRect(            // basic constructor
00386     int dd,                // dimension of space
00387     KMcoord l=0,            // default is empty
00388     KMcoord h=0)
00389     {  lo = kmAllocPt(dd, l);  hi = kmAllocPt(dd, h);  }
00390 
00391     KMorthRect(            // (almost a) copy constructor
00392     int dd,                // dimension
00393     const KMorthRect &r)        // rectangle to copy
00394     {  lo = kmAllocCopyPt(dd, r.lo);  hi = kmAllocCopyPt(dd, r.hi); }
00395 
00396     KMorthRect(            // construct from points
00397     int dd,                // dimension
00398     KMpoint l,            // low point
00399     KMpoint h)            // hight point
00400     {  lo = kmAllocCopyPt(dd, l);  hi = kmAllocCopyPt(dd, h);  }
00401 
00402     ~KMorthRect()            // destructor
00403     {  kmDeallocPt(lo);  kmDeallocPt(hi); }
00404 
00405     bool inside(int dim, KMpoint p);    // is point p inside rectangle?
00406                         // expand by factor x and store in r
00407     void expand(int dim, double x, KMorthRect r);
00408     void sample(int dim, KMpoint p);    // sample point p uniformly
00409 };
00410 
00411 void kmAssignRect(        // assign one rect to another
00412     int            dim,        // dimension (both must be same)
00413     KMorthRect        &dest,        // destination (modified)
00414     const KMorthRect    &source);    // source
00415 
00416 #endif
